author: shresth
content:
I am trying to better understand the sync protocol from Altair upgrade:
1. I don't completely get the requirement of FinalisedHeader in the light client update container. I am not clear that if the Sync Committee signs the tip of the chain or the last Finalised Header? How can there be a case where the Finalised Header is not defined and the Attested Header is the Finalised Header? 
2. I don't see the spec changes for blockProposer on how the Sync Committee signatures are handled. Eg.  Does blockProposer only consider the attestation that he would agree as the last block?  Also what other checks does the blockProposer makes
3. I don't see the spec changes in the attestation rules. Eg. given that I am in the Sync Committee which header do I sign, etc

author: dapplion
content: Can you just craft a fake state that points to a random finalized checkpoint of your interest and get that signed by rogue sync committee participants?

author: ralexstokes
content:
> 1. I don't completely get the requirement of FinalisedHeader in the light client update container. I am not clear that if the Sync Committee signs the tip of the chain or the last Finalised Header? How can there be a case where the Finalised Header is not defined and the Attested Header is the Finalised Header? 
the sync committee signature in a block is always signing over the previous block root

separately, a light client can request an update and if the provider wants to provide finality information they can w/ the finalized header, but it is optional

> 2. I don't see the spec changes for blockProposer on how the Sync Committee signatures are handled. Eg.  Does blockProposer only consider the attestation that he would agree as the last block?  Also what other checks does the blockProposer makes
the details are here: https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/blob/dev/specs/altair/validator.md
in short, the producer aggregates sync committee signatures that match their view of the chain and includes them in their block

> 3. I don't see the spec changes in the attestation rules. Eg. given that I am in the Sync Committee which header do I sign, etc
the sync committee responsibility is bit distinct from the attestation responsibility, as part of the sync committee you sign over the previous block root as validated here: https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/blob/dev/specs/altair/beacon-chain.md#sync-aggregate-processing

author: ralexstokes
content:
yes, i was thinking about this and what i said above was wrong or at least a bit misleading

you'd need broader knowledge of the chain activity than what you'd get from the current light client design which has a honest majority requirement on the sync committee
